title: 110_s1650
content: The "Max Cleland Minority Serving Institution Digital and Wireless Technology Opportunity Act" establishes an Office of Minority Serving Institution Digital and Wireless Technology within the National Science Foundation. The Office aims to strengthen eligible institutions' capacity for digital and wireless network technology instruction and enhance the national digital and wireless infrastructure through grants, contracts, and cooperative agreements. An eligible institution can use funding from the Act to acquire equipment, develop educational services in STEM fields, provide technology training for teachers and individuals, and collaborate on technology education projects with education agencies. The Act allows eligible institutions to receive funding for professional development in STEM fields, capacity-building technical assistance, fostering the use of information communications technology, and developing proposals for submission. To develop proposals and strategic plans for information technology investments under this Act. SEC. 4. APPLICATION AND REVIEW PROCEDURE. To be eligible for funding under this Act, eligible institutions must submit an application to the Director, who will establish a procedure for reviewing applications with input from an advisory council. The council will advise on involving institutions in program activities and evaluating proposals. The advisory council for the program includes representatives from technology and telecommunications institutions, minority businesses, eligible institution communities, Federal agencies, and individuals knowledgeable about technology issues. Panel reviewing proposals must include members from minority serving institutions. Program review criteria consider demonstrated need for assistance and diversity among institutions. Eligible institutions receiving funding must provide relevant institutional data to the Office. The Director will convene an annual meeting of eligible institutions to foster collaboration, capacity-building activities, and disseminate information generated by the meetings. SEC. 5. MATCHING REQUIREMENT. The Director must not award a grant, contract, or cooperative agreement unless the institution agrees to provide non-Federal contributions equal to 25% of the funding amount or $500,000, whichever is less. The matching requirement can be waived for institutions with no significant endowment. SEC. 6. LIMITATIONS. SEC. 6. LIMITATIONS. An eligible institution receiving a grant over $2,500,000 cannot receive another grant until all other eligible institutions have been awarded. Grants must be administered by the eligible institution. SEC. 7. ANNUAL REPORT AND EVALUATION. Each institution receiving a grant must provide an annual report on its use of the funding. The Director evaluates the program every 2 years based on these reports, assessing the impact on students, faculty, and staff. A report is then submitted to Congress. The Director evaluates the program every 2 years based on annual reports from grant-receiving institutions. A report with recommendations for Federal support is submitted to Congress. SEC. 8. DEFINITIONS. An eligible institution, as defined in this Act, includes historically Black colleges, Hispanic-serving institutions, tribally controlled colleges, Alaska Native-serving institutions, and Native Hawaiian-serving institutions. The Director of the National Science Foundation determines institutions that have enrolled a substantial number of minority, low-income students receiving assistance under Title IV of the Higher Education Act. Authorization of appropriations of $250,000,000 for each fiscal year 2008 through 2012 to the National Science Foundation for this Act.
